abstracts.cdata!:
The Paper Rehabilitation Project for
            Turkey is not rated because there is insufficient
            information as to the impact of the Bank's technical
            and advisory involvement in Turkey's pulp and paper
            subsector. No audit is planned. The loan was approved by the
            Board on May 23, 1985, signed on May 29, 1985, and made
            effective on September 17, 1985. At the request of the
            Government, the project was cancelled on August 4, 1986.
            Start-up of the project was stalled due to disagreements
            between the Turkish Pulp and Paper Enterprise (SEKA) and the
            Bank on the selection of consultants for the preparation of
            detailed engineering design and project management. A number
            of potential bidders claimed to the Bank that they had been
            accorded unequal treatment. The Bank advised the Government
            and SEKA to cancel the selection process and invite new
            proposals. Ultimately, this issue could not be resolved and
            the Government requested the Bank to cancel the undisbursed
            amount. The Government agreed to pre-pay the outstanding
            balance, consisting of disbursements for a project
            preparation facility and the interest and commitment
            charges. At the time of cancellation, work had already begun
            on the Pulp and Paper Subsector Study. As the Government
            deemed the study important, financing was made available
            under a separate Technical Assistance for State Economic
            Enterprises Project. The report states that the Bank doubted
            the Government's cited reasons of the consultant
            selection process and the possibility of privatization of
            SEKA as rationales for cancellation. Rather, it may well
            have been a reassessment on the part of the Government of
            the need for further investments in SEKA that precipitated
            the cancellation decision. As a result, the Bank's
            decision to accede to the Government's request was appropriate.
